summary: Marvel Releases High-Res Avengers: Endgame Spoiler Images
title: Marvel Releases High-Res Avengers: Endgame Spoiler Images
body:
Marvel Releases High-Res #AvengersEndgame Spoiler Images

With Avengers: Endgame safely in theaters and breaking box office records, most people on the planet have seen it already. That means it’s safe for Marvel to be a bit looser with spoilers, as the recent TV spots have shown.

They’ve now released eight high-res images that are mostly from late in the movie in the final battle, although there is one of Professor Hulk from earlier in the film:

[ngg…

View On WordPress

tags: turns out seeing it done wrong is a far better illustration than seeing it done right
summary: Apologies to Oscar Wilde and all my professors, but the one-two punch of Avengers: Endgame and the final season of Game of...
body: Apologies to Oscar Wilde and all my professors, but the one-two punch of Avengers: Endgame and the final season of Game of Thrones has taught me more about “art for art’s sake” than an entire semester studying The Picture of Dorian Gray could have ever hoped to.

reblog.comment: Apologies to Oscar Wilde and all my professors, but the one-two punch of Avengers: Endgame and the final season of Game of Thrones has taught me more about “art for art’s sake” than an entire semester studying The Picture of Dorian Gray could have ever hoped to.

trail.content_raw: Apologies to Oscar Wilde and all my professors, but the one-two punch of Avengers: Endgame and the final season of Game of Thrones has taught me more about “art for art’s sake” than an entire semester studying The Picture of Dorian Gray could have ever hoped to.
trail.content: Apologies to Oscar Wilde and all my professors, but the one-two punch of Avengers: Endgame and the final season of Game of Thrones has taught me more about “art for art’s sake” than an entire semester studying The Picture of Dorian Gray could have ever hoped to.

tags: stickies and starons being miserable together?
it's like all my birthdays at once
summary:
Oh also, just to make my position on Endgame and the end of Steve's arc perfectly clear -
I LOVE it. I was ambivalent about it...
body:
Oh also, just to make my position on Endgame and the end of Steve’s arc perfectly clear -

I LOVE it. I was ambivalent about it when I came out of the theatre. But seeing the absolute bitchfit Stuckies and Starons are throwing because Steve refused to dick down their self inserts is giving me life.

Cry more bitches. Your ship’s still not canon. Will never be canon. And Bucket and Sharon will forever be irrelevant because whatever relationship they had with Steve was the only thing making them relevant.

And I know that’s a hard fucking pill to swallow and I’m glad you’re choking on it lmaooo.

blog.name: artemisegeria
blog.title: This Is Not The Endgame
blog.description: Unapologetic Vision and Wanda Maximoff Stan

summary: More Random Endgame Questions (Spoilers)
title: More Random Endgame Questions (Spoilers)
body:
I just saw Endgame for a third time. And I’m still confused. I could definitely be missing things, but I just don’t know. 

As I keep working on various fix-its, I am forced to confront things that Endgame left up in the air, at least to my understanding. Most of these things I would be able to let go if I weren’t trying to write fics around them in a way that makes a modicum of sense.

1. Can Thor summon the Bifrost with Stormbreaker? I thought Infinity War and Ragnarok implied that Thor could do it and Stormbreaker could help, but did Thor lose that power when he declared Valkyrie the Queen of New Asgard? Or does he still have it as the rightful son of Odin who has now unlocked his full power? Does he require Stormbreaker or can he summon it himself? 

2. When Cap came back to the main timeline to give Sam the shield, was he intending to stay or was he only dropping by? Was alternate universe Peggy already dead? Was the alternate universe that Steve went back in time to the same one where 2014 Thanos was already gone, or were multiple alternate universes created? Did Steve return to 1945 after dropping off the Tesseract in 1970, or did he just stay in 1970? I couldn’t tell based on the cars in the final scene. Was old Steve himself close to death? He seemed pretty healthy in that scene, just old. Did he talk to anyone else or was he trying to keep his presence quiet? Wouldn’t his very presence back in the main timeline create a new alternate universe going forward? 

3. Where did Steve live and what he did he do when he wasn’t leading group therapy sessions during the five year time jump? Nat makes a joke, asking him if he’s at the compound to do his washing. This implies to me me that he did not live there full-time. So does this mean he was not involved in any of the Avenging activities that Nat, Rhodey, etc. were doing? Or only some of the time?

4. One thing that didn’t register with me until now is: how did Scott Lang’s things get into storage? Was it a government program for all the missing people? There seemed to be a number of other compartments, and it is funny that Lang’s identification number on his sign was 616. Or did Maggie and Jim survive the Snap, Scott’s stuff was given to them, and they put it in storage? It seems like other vehicles and things were just abandoned? Why wasn’t Scott’s stuff just abandoned? Is there a good in-universe explanation or is it just the needs of the plot?

I don’t know that there are clear answers to any of these questions, so I am treating the answers to all of them as: “Whatever I want.” But it would be nice to have just a little more canonical detail.

summary: One Marvel Hero Had To Be Added To Endgame's Women-Of-Marvel Sequence Via Digital Effects
title: One Marvel Hero Had To Be Added To Endgame's Women-Of-Marvel Sequence Via Digital Effects
excerpt: Sometimes schedules don’t mesh perfectly, and that’s where VFX work comes in.
description:
It’s safe to say that the final battle in Avengers: Endgame, where 2014 Thanos and his forces clashed with all the MCU heroes and their accompanying allies, is the biggest action packed sequence of the Marvel Cinematic Universe thus far. Among the notable moments was when all the Marvel heroines (except for Black Widow, who died earlier) came together to ensure that the Infinity Gauntlet reached the quantum tunnel inside Scott Lang’s van.

Ironically, it turns out that the one male hero who was around for this sequence, Spider-Man, was digitally inserted into this Women-Of-Marvel sequence after the main shoot. I recently had the opportunity to speak with Weta Digital visual effects supervisor Matt Aiken, and here’s what he had to say about Tom Holland’s absence:

The only person who wasn’t able to be there on that day was Tom Holland, and Spidey has to hand the Gauntlet off to Captain Marvel at the start of that shot, so we had a stand-in for Spidey and we ended up filming him with a kind of faux-motion control rig a couple of weeks later when Tom Holland became available, and we tracked him into that shot and popped him in.

It’s a wonder that so much of Avengers: Endgame’s climactic conflict managed to have all the actors together on stage, but this is one instance where schedules weren’t 100% able to mesh together. Peter Parker was shown interacting with Brie Larson’s Captain Marvel and watching as all these heroines teamed up on the battlefield, but in reality, Tom Holland had to participate in this sequence on his own. At least Matt Aiken and his VFX team at WETA made Holland inclusion as seamless as possible.

Like everyone else who was dusted at the end of Avengers: Infinity War, Spider-Man didn’t show up until after the battle over the destroyed Avengers base had already unfolded. Despite his limited screen time, he managed to stand out not just as the catalyst for the Women-Of-Marvel sequence, but also through the touching reunion with his mentor and father figure, Tony Stark, although their time together was tragically short as Tony would later sacrifice his life to stop Thanos’ forces.

While ultimately the Marvel heroines’ efforts in this portion of Avengers: Endgame were for naught since Thanos destroyed the van containing the Quantum Realm technology, the Women-Of-Marvel sequence as a whole was still exciting to watch. In the last couple years, various MCU actresses have talked about wanting the franchise to deliver a movie starring a female-led team, and this Endgame sequence provided a good case for such a project.

summary: Hey Ashley, what's the significance of Captain being able to summon/wield Thor's hammer? It got such a huge reaction on opening...
question: Hey Ashley, what's the significance of Captain being able to summon/wield Thor's hammer? It got such a huge reaction on opening night, and I just sat there clapping along with everyone else in the movie theater. I enjoyed the spectacle of the entire movie, but I felt like a fraud, lol!
answer: 😂 That is hilarious. So yeah, the quick MCU backstory on Thor’s hammer, Mjolnir, is that most people cannot pick it up. You have to be deemed worthy. (Even Thor couldn’t wield it for a while.) So there’s this whole scene in Avengers: Age of Ultron where all the Avengers are hanging out at a party and each of them try to pick it up. Tony can’t even do it with his Iron Man hand. So then Steve goes, and it budges ever-so-slightly, which Thor notices and his arrogant smile immediately drops. I was never really sure whether Steve noticed because he doesn’t let on; instead, he immediately gives up. (Side note: Later in the movie, we see Vision pick it up with ease, which I think was completely unnecessary and dampens this sweet victory just a little bit.) But yeah, that’s why everyone lost their shit and Thor was like, “I knew it!” We’ve all been waiting for the followup to that moment since 2015, lol. (Cap can also wield the hammer in the comics, so I’m sure fans of that were also super happy about seeing it on screen.) And thank you for reminding me just how great that was. 😩

summary: spider-man: homecoming, black panther, cap 1
question: spider-man: homecoming, black panther, cap 1
answer:
Please note this answer has spoilers for Avengers: Endgame.

1) Spider-Man: Homecoming is my favorite solo MCU movie. It’s #3 all-time behind Endgame & Infinity War. I credit Kevin Feige with bringing the Peter Parker I love from the comics to life. Okay, so he’s not 1:1 with 616 Peter or Ultimate Peter, but his personality is beautifully adapted. You’ve got the villain with a personal stake in his life; the awkwardness around his crush; the super brains; the trying to have a secret identity while blatantly jumping into action when he sees someone in need; the adoration with other superheroes (early Spidey, this was the Fantastic Four); and even though it’s been recontextualized as a mentor/mentee relationship, his working relationship with Iron Man. I also love what’s been changed because it works so well with the MCU, like his suit having AI Karen; MJ having model-worthy looks but not flaunting them and really being a muted, sarcastic foil to Peter; Flash being less of a 1960s-type jock bully and more of a smartass; and Ned being his close friend as a version of Ganke rather than jumping right into Harry Osborn. It’s also incredibly important in retrospect that this movie is integral to Tony Stark’s arc in Phase 3. This movie gives Infinity War and Endgame its emotional gravitas. Tony may have had a kid of his own by 2023, but Peter Parker is the catalyst for everything.

2) Black Panther is incredibly important to cinema as a whole in 2018 and beyond, not just to the MCU. Top-notch acting by Boseman, Nyong’o, and Jordan with a script that ties back into Age of Ultron and Civil War while still being standalone. Killmonger is one of the MCU’s best villains and this film has incredibly personal stakes, a killer art and sound direction, and Marvel’s first Oscar wins. It’s an enjoyable watch that proves to the naysayers superhero franchises can also have cinematic objective quality (which we’ve all been saying all along).

3) Captain America: The First Avenger is like a bowl of chicken noodle soup. It’s not 5-star quality but it warms the soul and the heart like an old friend. MCU Captain America is my favorite hero in the franchise and this movie gave new life to a hero many passed off as outdated propaganda. I can watch The First Avenger all day. What makes that special? Nothing, I’m just a kid from Florida who loves how cheesy but serious this one gets. (Also, Steggy.)

Send me 3 Marvel movies (or anything, really) and I’ll rank them best to worst!
